document.masterDocTitle: A review of the zumpti species group of the genus Harpyrhynchoides (Acariformes: Harpirhynchidae) — ectoparasites of passerines

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the zumpti species group of the genus Harpyrhynchoides (Acariformes: Harpirhynchidae) — ectoparasites of passerines

bibRefCitation.author: Bochkov
bibRefCitation.refString: Bochkov, A. V. & Galloway, T. D. (2013) New records and new species of mites of the subfamily Harpirhynchinae (Acariformes: Harpirhynchidae) infesting birds in Manitoba, Canada. Acta Parasitologica, 58, 405 - 419. http: // dx. doi. org / 10.2478 / s 11686 - 013 - 0172 - 4

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis . FEMALE. Palp femoragenu with distinct lateral notches. Palpalae l”G 1.7–2 times longer than dF . Body, including gnathosoma, 280–330 (in specimens from
Catharus ustulatus
in USA about 360 long). Setae
h 2
55–80 long. Vulva without long lateral folds. Genua I and II with 3 setae ( v ” absent). Apical segment of legs III with 5 setae, apical segment of legs IV with 4 setae.

Type material
. Holotype female ( CNCI ),
25 female
and
5 male
paratypes ( AVB ZISP 13 -0325-008, 1-30 ) from
Junco hyemalis (Linnaeus)
( Passeriformes : Emberizidae ), Manitoba, Winnipeg, Summerland,
4 October 2003
coll. T.D. Galloway and D. Holder (SM 1169 # 4 );
10 female
paratypes ( AVB ZISP 13 -0325-009, 1–10 ) from same host and locality,
4 October 2003
, coll. T.D. Galloway and D. Holder (SM 1170 # 3 );
12 female
paratypes ( AVB ZISP 13 -0325-010, 1–12 ) from same host and locality,
7 April 2004
, coll. T.D. Galloway and D. Holder (SM 1302 ).

6 females
from

,

Hosts and distribution . This species is known from the various North American passerines belonging to the families Emberizidae , Turdidae , and Cardinalidae (
Bochkov and Galloway 2013 ; present paper
).
Moss ( 1979 )
misidentified mites from
Junco hyemalis , Melospiza melodia , Passerella iliaca , Calamospiza melanocorys
( Emberizidae ),
Sialia currucoides
( Turdidae ), and Passerina amoena ( Cardinalidae ) as
H. brevis
.
